awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Carbon Isotope and geotracer-enabled simulation of the Transient Climate Evolution of the Deglacial Ocean (C-iTRACE-O)
awd_abstract_narration:
Global climate has undergone large changes during the last deglaciation (21,000 to 11,000 years ago), with a warming of ~3.5°C globally, a sea level rise of ~80 m, and the disappearance of the large continental ice sheets. The large magnitude of the signals and the availability of extensive paleoclimate data make this period an excellent target for investigating the mechanisms underlying climate change and for the validation of state-of-the-art Earth System Models (ESMs). However, up until now model simulations could not be directly compared with the paleoclimate records, as the models did not simulate the geochemical tracers ("proxies") on which the reconstructions are based. To address this issue and provide insights into several long-standing scientific questions about the evolution of the ocean's overturning circulation during the deglaciation, this project will perform the first transient ocean simulation of the deglaciation with the newly developed isotope modules in the ocean model of the Community Earth System Model (CESM1), allowing for direct model-data comparison of multiple marine paleo proxies. This project will contribute to STEM workforce development by supporting the training of two graduate students in climate modeling and model-data comparisons and by providing project leadership experience for an early career female scientist, who will work in close collaboration with U.S. and international colleagues. Results from this project will be used in undergraduate and graduate classes at the University of Colorado at Boulder and the University of Wisconsin-Madison and will be incorporated into public outreach through a project website and through general-audience talks. The output of the simulation (called C-iTRACE-O) will be made freely available though the Earth System Grid gateway, allowing the entire paleoclimate community to use it for their research. The simulation will also be contributed to the Paleoclimate Model Intercomparison Project transient deglacial working group, allowing for an evaluation of the CESM C-iTRACE compared to the deglacial simulations from other ESMs.

By directly simulating oceanic carbon-isotopes (d13C and D14C), Neodymium (eNd), and Protactinium/Thorium (231Pa/230Th) for the deglaciation and by carrying out sensitivity experiments to investigate the physical mechanisms causing the changing isotopic and geotracer distributions in the transient simulation, it will be possible to address some long-standing scientific questions through direct comparisons to observations and by evaluating tracer-circulation relationships in the model itself, such as:

- What was the source and routing of the low-radiocarbon CO2 released during the Mystery Interval? 
- What is the implication of the d13C evolution in the Atlantic for the deep ocean circulation during the last deglaciation and how much of the d13C change was caused by nutrient- and air-sea gas exchange effects versus circulation changes? 
- Why is the deglacial evolution of Antarctic Intermediate Water controversial among proxies, notably in eNd and carbon isotopes? 
- How does 231Pa/ 230Th represent the deglacial evolution of North Atlantic deep circulation and Southern Ocean upwelling?

por.por_cntn:
This project had two main goals:

1)    Perform and share with the community the first transient deglacial simulation from 21,000 years ago to today with important ocean geotracers, namely carbon isotopes (13C and 14C), Neodymium (Nd), Protactinium/Thorium (231Pa/ 230Th) and water isotopes (δ18O) in the ocean model from the Community Earth System Model (CESM). This simulation is called CiTRACE. By including these geotracers in the model we can more directly compare climate model simulations of past climates with proxy reconstructions of past climate, which rely on these (and other) isotopes.

2)    Analyze the CiTRACE simulation to answer scientific questions about the climate evolution during the deglaciation by directly comparing the modeled geotracers to paleo proxies.

We have achieved both goals, with the CiTRACE deglacial simulation from 21,000 to present day completed and the simulation output publicly available at https://gdex.ucar.edu/dataset/204_ajahn.html and documented at https://sites.google.com/colorado.edu/citrace. We have documented the development of geotracers used in CiTRACE and the hybrid forcing used to force CiTRACE in the peer-reviewed literature (Gu et al., 2019; Zhang et al., 2017) as well as analyzed the CiTRACE simulation and published the results in peer-reviewed journals (Gu et al., 2019, 2020, 2021, Zanowski et al., 2022). In addition, as planned as part of the broader impacts of the project, this project has provided training opportunities for several students and postdoctoral researchers in paleo climate research and all journal articles from the project were lead-authored by a current or former student or postdoctoral researcher.

In terms of scientific results, we were able to use the new ocean tracers included in CiTRACE to address several open scientific questions about physical mechanisms that affect the isotope concentrations that are used to reconstruct the deglacial ocean circulation. For example, we were able to use CiTRACE to show that Δ14C is not solely a circulation age tracer, as changes in surface reservoir ages also affect the simulated Δ14C changes in the Pacific during the deglaciation during some periods by controlling as much as half of the Δ14C change (Zanowski et al., 2022). We also showed that the degree to which surface reservoir age controls Δ14C changes also varies spatially across the Pacific, with important implications for how we interpret paleo proxy records from sediment cores around this region. Similarly, we were able to use CiTRACE to show that the overserved decrease in δ13C during the Heinrich Stadial 1, when the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) weakened, is due to increased remineralization due to the AMOC-induced mid-depth ocean ventilation decreases (Gu et al., 2021). From proxy records alone, it was not possible to quantify whether remineralization or a greater fraction of δ13C depleted southern sourced water dominated the observed δ13C change in the North Atlantic, but with the CiTRACE simulation we were able to quantify their relative contributions. We also assessed how well commonly used paleo proxies for reconstructing the strength of the AMOC capture actual changes in AMOC strength in the CiTRACE simulation. Specifically, we assessed whether the deglacial zonal δ18Oc contrast across the Atlantic can represent AMOC changes and found that the δ18Oc contrast across the western boundary along the entire Atlantic and the basin-wide δ18Oc contrast in the North Atlantic in the upper ocean can also be used to reconstruct AMOC strength (Gu et al., 2019). When assessing the ability to use 231Pa/230Th changes as a proxy for AMOC intensity, we found that 231Pa/230Th does not only respond to changes in AMOC strength but also to changes in AMOC geometry (Gu et al., 2020).
